name: RequestGroup
description: A group of related requests that can be used to capture intended activities that have inter-dependencies such as "give this medication after that one".

properties.name: RequestGroup
properties.definition: A group of related requests that can be used to capture intended activities that have inter-dependencies such as "give this medication after that one".

properties.name: id
properties.definition: The logical id of the resource, as used in the URL for the resource. Once assigned, this value never changes.
properties.comment: The only time that a resource does not have an id is when it is being submitted to the server using a create operation.

properties.name: meta
properties.definition: The metadata about the resource. This is content that is maintained by the infrastructure. Changes to the content might not always be associated with version changes to the resource.

properties.name: implicitRules
properties.short: A set of rules under which this content was created
properties.definition: A reference to a set of rules that were followed when the resource was constructed, and which must be understood when processing the content. Often, this is a reference to an implementation guide that defines the special rules along with other profiles etc.
properties.comment: Asserting this rule set restricts the content to be only understood by a limited set of trading partners. This inherently limits the usefulness of the data in the long term. However, the existing health eco-system is highly fractured, and not yet ready to define, collect, and exchange data in a generally computable sense. Wherever possible, implementers and/or specification writers should avoid using this element. Often, when used, the URL is a reference to an implementation guide that defines these special rules as part of it's narrative along with other profiles, value sets, etc.

properties.name: language
properties.definition: The base language in which the resource is written.
properties.comment: Language is provided to support indexing and accessibility (typically, services such as text to speech use the language tag). The html language tag in the narrative applies  to the narrative. The language tag on the resource may be used to specify the language of other presentations generated from the data in the resource. Not all the content has to be in the base language. The Resource.language should not be assumed to apply to the narrative automatically. If a language is specified, it should it also be specified on the div element in the html (see rules in HTML5 for information about the relationship between xml:lang and the html lang attribute).

properties.name: text
properties.short: Text summary of the resource, for human interpretation
properties.definition: A human-readable narrative that contains a summary of the resource and can be used to represent the content of the resource to a human. The narrative need not encode all the structured data, but is required to contain sufficient detail to make it "clinically safe" for a human to just read the narrative. Resource definitions may define what content should be represented in the narrative to ensure clinical safety.
properties.comment: Contained resources do not have narrative. Resources that are not contained SHOULD have a narrative. In some cases, a resource may only have text with little or no additional discrete data (as long as all minOccurs=1 elements are satisfied).  This may be necessary for data from legacy systems where information is captured as a "text blob" or where text is additionally entered raw or narrated and encoded information is added later.

properties.name: contained
properties.definition: These resources do not have an independent existence apart from the resource that contains them - they cannot be identified independently, and nor can they have their own independent transaction scope.
properties.comment: This should never be done when the content can be identified properly, as once identification is lost, it is extremely difficult (and context dependent) to restore it again. Contained resources may have profiles and tags In their meta elements, but SHALL NOT have security labels.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the resource and that modifies the understanding of the element that contains it and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer is allowed to define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: identifier
properties.definition: Allows a service to provide a unique, business identifier for the request.

properties.name: instantiatesCanonical
properties.definition: A canonical URL referencing a FHIR-defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this request.

properties.name: instantiatesUri
properties.definition: A URL referencing an externally defined protocol, guideline, orderset or other definition that is adhered to in whole or in part by this request.

properties.name: basedOn
properties.definition: A plan, proposal or order that is fulfilled in whole or in part by this request.

properties.name: replaces
properties.definition: Completed or terminated request(s) whose function is taken by this new request.
properties.comment: The replacement could be because the initial request was immediately rejected (due to an issue) or because the previous request was completed, but the need for the action described by the request remains ongoing.

properties.name: groupIdentifier
properties.short: Composite request this is part of
properties.definition: A shared identifier common to all requests that were authorized more or less simultaneously by a single author, representing the identifier of the requisition, prescription or similar form.
properties.comment: Requests are linked either by a "basedOn" relationship (i.e. one request is fulfilling another) or by having a common requisition.  Requests that are part of the same requisition are generally treated independently from the perspective of changing their state or maintaining them after initial creation.

properties.name: status
properties.short: draft | active | on-hold | revoked | completed | entered-in-error | unknown
properties.definition: The current state of the request. For request groups, the status reflects the status of all the requests in the group.

properties.name: intent
properties.short: proposal | plan | directive | order | original-order | reflex-order | filler-order | instance-order | option
properties.definition: Indicates the level of authority/intentionality associated with the request and where the request fits into the workflow chain.

properties.name: priority
properties.definition: Indicates how quickly the request should be addressed with respect to other requests.

properties.name: code
properties.definition: A code that identifies what the overall request group is.
properties.comment: This element can be used to provide a code that captures the meaning of the request group as a whole, as opposed to the code of the action element, which captures the meaning of the individual actions within the request group.

properties.name: subject
properties.short: Who the request group is about
properties.definition: The subject for which the request group was created.

properties.name: encounter
properties.definition: Describes the context of the request group, if any.

properties.name: authoredOn
properties.short: When the request group was authored
properties.definition: Indicates when the request group was created.

properties.name: author
properties.short: Device or practitioner that authored the request group
properties.definition: Provides a reference to the author of the request group.

properties.name: reasonCode
properties.short: Why the request group is needed
properties.definition: Describes the reason for the request group in coded or textual form.

properties.name: reasonReference
properties.short: Why the request group is needed
properties.definition: Indicates another resource whose existence justifies this request group.

properties.name: note
properties.definition: Provides a mechanism to communicate additional information about the response.

properties.name: action
properties.definition: The actions, if any, produced by the evaluation of the artifact.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: prefix
properties.short: User-visible prefix for the action (e.g. 1. or A.)
properties.definition: A user-visible prefix for the action.

properties.name: title
properties.definition: The title of the action displayed to a user.

properties.name: description
properties.definition: A short description of the action used to provide a summary to display to the user.

properties.name: textEquivalent
properties.short: Static text equivalent of the action, used if the dynamic aspects cannot be interpreted by the receiving system
properties.definition: A text equivalent of the action to be performed. This provides a human-interpretable description of the action when the definition is consumed by a system that might not be capable of interpreting it dynamically.

properties.name: priority
properties.definition: Indicates how quickly the action should be addressed with respect to other actions.

properties.name: code
properties.short: Code representing the meaning of the action or sub-actions
properties.definition: A code that provides meaning for the action or action group. For example, a section may have a LOINC code for a section of a documentation template.

properties.name: documentation
properties.short: Supporting documentation for the intended performer of the action
properties.definition: Didactic or other informational resources associated with the action that can be provided to the CDS recipient. Information resources can include inline text commentary and links to web resources.

properties.name: condition
properties.short: Whether or not the action is applicable
properties.definition: An expression that describes applicability criteria, or start/stop conditions for the action.
properties.comment: When multiple conditions of the same kind are present, the effects are combined using AND semantics, so the overall condition is true only if all of the conditions are true.

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension.
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: modifierExtension
properties.short: Extensions that cannot be ignored even if unrecognized
properties.definition:
May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. Though any implementer can define an extension, there is a set of requirements that SHALL be met as part of the definition of the extension. Applications processing a resource are required to check for modifier extensions.

Modifier extensions SHALL NOT change the meaning of any elements on Resource or DomainResource (including cannot change the meaning of modifierExtension itself).
properties.comment: There can be no stigma associated with the use of extensions by any application, project, or standard - regardless of the institution or jurisdiction that uses or defines the extensions.  The use of extensions is what allows the FHIR specification to retain a core level of simplicity for everyone.

properties.name: kind
properties.definition: The kind of condition.
properties.comment: Applicability criteria are used to determine immediate applicability when a plan definition is applied to a given context. Start and stop criteria are carried through application and used to describe enter/exit criteria for an action.

properties.name: expression
properties.definition: An expression that returns true or false, indicating whether or not the condition is satisfied.
properties.comment: The expression may be inlined, or may be a reference to a named expression within a logic library referenced by the library element.

properties.name: relatedAction
properties.definition: A relationship to another action such as "before" or "30-60 minutes after start of".

properties.name: id
properties.definition: Unique id for the element within a resource (for internal references). This may be any string value that does not contain spaces.

properties.name: extension
properties.definition: May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance  applied to the definition and use of extensions. May be used to represent additional information that is not part of the basic definition of the element and that modifies the understanding of the element in which it is contained and/or the understanding of the containing element's descendants. Usually modifier elements provide negation or qualification. To make the use of extensions safe and manageable, there is a strict set of governance applied to the definition and use of extensions. properties.name: actionId
properties.short: What action this is related to
properties.definition: The element id of the action this is related to.

properties.name: relationship
properties.short: before-start | before | before-end | concurrent-with-start | concurrent | concurrent-with-end | after-start | after | after-end
properties.definition: The relationship of this action to the related action.

properties.name: offset[x]
properties.definition: A duration or range of durations to apply to the relationship. For example, 30-60 minutes before.

properties.name: timing[x]
properties.short: When the action should take place
properties.definition: An optional value describing when the action should be performed.

properties.name: participant
properties.definition: The participant that should perform or be responsible for this action.

properties.name: type
properties.definition: The type of action to perform (create, update, remove).

properties.name: groupingBehavior
properties.definition: Defines the grouping behavior for the action and its children.

properties.name: selectionBehavior
properties.short: any | all | all-or-none | exactly-one | at-most-one | one-or-more
properties.definition: Defines the selection behavior for the action and its children.

properties.name: requiredBehavior
properties.definition: Defines expectations around whether an action is required.

properties.name: precheckBehavior
properties.definition: Defines whether the action should usually be preselected.

properties.name: cardinalityBehavior
properties.definition: Defines whether the action can be selected multiple times.

properties.name: resource
properties.definition: The resource that is the target of the action (e.g. CommunicationRequest).
properties.comment: The target resource SHALL be a [Request](request.html) resource with a Request.intent set to "option".

properties.name: action
properties.definition: Sub actions.

searchParameters.name: author
searchParameters.description: The author of the request group

searchParameters.name: authored
searchParameters.description: The date the request group was authored

searchParameters.name: code
searchParameters.description: The code of the request group

searchParameters.name: encounter
searchParameters.description: The encounter the request group applies to

searchParameters.name: group-identifier
searchParameters.description: The group identifier for the request group

searchParameters.name: identifier
searchParameters.description: External identifiers for the request group

searchParameters.name: instantiates-canonical
searchParameters.description: The FHIR-based definition from which the request group is realized

searchParameters.name: instantiates-uri
searchParameters.description: The external definition from which the request group is realized

searchParameters.name: intent
searchParameters.description: The intent of the request group

searchParameters.name: participant
searchParameters.description: The participant in the requests in the group

searchParameters.name: patient
searchParameters.description: The identity of a patient to search for request groups

searchParameters.name: priority
searchParameters.description: The priority of the request group

searchParameters.name: status
searchParameters.description: The status of the request group

searchParameters.name: subject
searchParameters.description: The subject that the request group is about

searchParameters.name: priority-order
searchParameters.description: Numeric priority order for resource types using http://hl7.org/fhir/ValueSet/request-priority
